A stretch along the Cardassian border that ships try to stay away from... a lot of plasma storms in the area...
A couple of ships have been lost there over the past year or two...
Sounds like the perfect place for a hideout... Excuse me, sir -- but what do you plan to do if we catch up with them? After all, these Maquis are Federation colonists...
We're going to get Gul Dukat back by any means necessary.
Even if we have to fire on our own people...
Long range sensors are picking up the warp signature... it leads to an M-class asteroid...
Take us there.
Scanning the surface... I've located the ship...
Those are human life signs...
Is there a Cardassian among them?
No, sir...
Prepare to beam down...
I'm glad to see you didn't have too much trouble finding us, Ben...
It seems that one disaster after another keeps bringing us back together again.
Ben, you should've seen the look on your face when you saw me standing there.
I hardly recognized you without your uniform.
Lately, it's been feeling a little tight on me.
Just like that?
(trying to convince himself as well) It's just a uniform, Ben.
Is that all it is? I remember when you first put it on.
The day we graduated from the Academy. We both swore we'd be starship captains by the time we were thirty.
And admirals by forty. I think we've both done pretty well for ourselves.

We did, didn't we. But now... now I've found something better. (re: his Maquis comrades) These settlers, Ben, if you saw all they've accomplished without any help from the Federation... you'd be fighting along with them.
I don't think so.
They've traveled out here to the back of the beyond and built homes out of the wilderness. Maybe the Federation can turn their backs on them, but I can't.
I'm not asking you to. But your joining the Maquis isn't helping anyone. Your actions have only endangered the treaty, put millions of lives at risk...
The Federation believes every problem can be solved with a treaty. But out here, on the frontier, without the power of the Federation to back it up, a treaty's just a piece of paper.
Do you have evidence that the Central Command has violated the treaty?
Not yet, but we will.
If you're depending on Gul Dukat for proof, you're going to be disappointed.
Why do you say that?
Because I don't think he knows.
We'll find out, won't we.
I want him back, Cal.
He's not here.
Then where is he?
I never thought I'd see the day where you'd side with a Cardassian against me.
Damn it, Cal. I'm on your side.
You have a funny way of showing it.

I'm trying to stop you from making the biggest mistake of your life. The Federation believes in this treaty. If you destroy it, Starfleet'll come after you, and they won't be satisfied until you're behind bars. But if we put a stop to this now... if we work together to end the violence...

The violence will never end as long as the Central Command keeps smuggling weapons to their colonies. (a beat, regaining his poise) I wish there was another way to handle this thing. I really do. No one wants peace more than the Maquis...
And you're willing to blow up Cardassian ships to get it.
The Bok'Nor won't ever smuggle weapons again.
And its crewmembers won't be going home to their families, either.
(continuing, pressing his advantage) Look, you say that the Central Command is behind the smuggling. Fine. Let's prove it.
How?
We'll go to Cardassia... find the evidence to back up your claim. And when we do, we'll take it to the Federation...
No. The Federation abandoned us. Told us to take care of ourselves. Well, that's what we intend to do. But you, Ben, you could be invaluable. Let us use your station.
For what?
Any number of things. A maintenance facility for our ships... a supply depot...
I can't allow that.
Every week, innocent people are being murdered by the Cardassians... and I won't allow their deaths to go unpunished.
You don't want peace, Cal. You want revenge.
I prefer to call it retaliation. I'm sorry we won't be working together, Benjamin. It would've been nice... like old times.
Commander!
Sorry, Ben.
Let's go. Knowing Ben's temper, we don't want to be here when he wakes up.
Lieutenant, I want to speak to the Cardassian Central Command.
Then you're in luck. Legate Parn will be arriving here within the hour.
A Legate. I feel honored. While I'm waiting, I'll talk with Starfleet.
Admiral Necheyev's already here.
Chief, The Maquis must have transferred Dukat off their ship before reaching that asteroid. I want to know where they've hid him.
I could retrace their warp trail. See if they met up with any other ships.
Do it.
Admiral...
(no time for pleasantries) Commander, the Cardassian Central Command has gone on military alert in response to the kidnapping of Gul Dukat.
I'm not surprised.
This Security Chief of yours... the shape-shifter.
Odo.
Odo. Are you sure you wouldn't be better off with a Starfleet officer heading up your security team.
Admiral, I have complete faith in Odo's ability to do his job.
If you say so, Commander.
I do. As for Gul Dukat, I assure you that we're taking all possible steps to locate him.
Good. Keep me informed of your progress.
I will. But Admiral, there's a bigger issue here than rescuing Dukat.
And what is that?
The Maquis.
The Maquis... are a bunch of irresponsible hotheads.
These "hotheads" are responsible for the bombing of the Bok'Nor.
I'm aware of that, Commander. We never should've allowed those colonists to remain on the Cardassian side of the Demilitarized Zone.
Well they're there, Admiral. And they're not leaving.
Don't they realize that they're jeopardizing our treaty with the Cardassians?
The Maquis never signed any treaty.
What about Commander Hudson? He's lived with these people. What's his analysis of the situation?
I'll... have to ask him.
You do that. I want you to find the Maquis, Commander... talk to them... remind them that they're citizens of the Federation... that it's imperative that we preserve the treaty with the Cardassians.
A treaty the Cardassians may not be honoring.
Are you questioning Federation policy, Commander?
All I know is that the situation in the Demilitarized Zone is deteriorating rapidly.
Personally, I think you're overstating the problem. Establish a dialogue with the Maquis. They're still Federation citizens. I'm sure they'll listen to reason. Good luck, Commander.
(to himself, incredulous) Establish a dialogue? What the hell does she think I've been trying to do?
Commander?
Just because a group of people belongs to the Federation doesn't mean they're saints.
Excuse me?
You know what the trouble is?
No...
The trouble is Earth.
Really?

On Earth there's no poverty, no crime, no war. You look out the window of Starfleet headquarters and you see... paradise. Well, it's easy to be a saint in paradise. But the Maquis don't live in paradise. Out there in the Demilitarized Zone, all the problems haven't been solved yet. Out there, there are no saints... just people. Angry, scared, determined people who are going to do whatever it takes to survive. Whether it meets with Federation approval or not.
Makes sense to me.
I'm glad someone understands.
Legate Parn's ship just put in at Docking Bay Five. Maybe you'd like to give him the same speech.
I just might do that.
Odo to Sisko.
Go ahead, Constable.
I think you'd better get down to security. I've caught one of the Vulcan's accomplices.
Commander, I assure you that I had no idea that Sakonna was planning to kidnap Gul Dukat.
Really. Then perhaps you can explain why the two of you were spending so much time together.
Surely it's no crime keeping company with a beautiful female. You ought to try it, Odo. It might improve your disposition.
Do you expect us to believe that a Vulcan would be interested in you for your lobes.
Vulcans are a species that appreciate good ears. Commander, this is very embarrassing, having to discuss my personal life in such surroundings.
Embarrassment is going to be the least of your problems unless you tell me what kind of business arrangement you had with that woman.
All right. But first I want to make it clear that I was led astray by Sakonna's feminine wiles.
Save the excuses, Quark. Tell us what you were up to.
Sakonna was in the market for certain items which I was able to obtain for her... at a considerable discount, I might add.
What items?
We're waiting.
Let's see, where to begin... she wanted some deflector shields... navigational arrays... maybe... a couple of hundred photon torpedoes.
Photon torpedoes.
And pulse cannons... and some high energy disrupters...
Weapons. You sold weapons to a terrorist group.
I did not. The Pygorians sold them the weapons. I merely... made some introductions. Besides, I hadn't even heard of the Maquis until after Dukat was kidnapped.
I want a complete list of every weapon she purchased.
Of course. And if you need some one to testify against Sakonna in court, I'd be more than willing...
Would you?
In a second. And let me know if there's anyone else who needs testifying against.
I'll tell you one thing, Commander, Sakonna was on a tight clock. Whatever she needed those weapons for, it's going to happen within the next few days.
Just get me the list, Quark.
Sir?
I assume you'll be going out to search for Dukat again?
As soon as O'Brien tells us where to look.
I'd like to join you. After all, I am in charge of security.
I'd be happy to have you along.
One other thing... How long do I keep him in here?
Forever.
I've always enjoyed the Commander's wry sense of humor. But really Odo, how long am I going to be in here?
I'll let you know.
Odo... this isn't funny. Odo...
Commander, this is Legate Parn. He insisted on seeing you immediately.
Crucial business demands immediate attention. And as a member of the Cardassian Central Command I must assure you, Commander, that what we have to discuss is most crucial indeed.
I understand. And I assure you that we're doing all we can to find Gul Dukat.

Please, Commander, your efforts are appreciated but unnecessary. You see the Central Command has learned that Gul Dukat was the leader of a small group of misguided officers who were funnelling weapons to our colonies in the Demilitarized Zone.
So the Maquis were right. The Cardassian settlers are being supplied by the Central Command.

Dukat and the others were operating entirely without our knowledge. The Central Command would never sanction anything that would violate our treaty with the Federation. We've arrested Dukat's co-conspirators and they'll be dealt with accordingly.
Where does that leave Dukat?
With the Maquis... Where he belongs.
Are you saying you don't want him back?
I assume the Maquis will execute him for his crimes.
I wouldn't be surprised.
Well then, I don't see where it makes a difference whether we do it or they do it.
How do we know they won't use Dukat's death as an excuse to send troops into the Demilitarized Zone?
I assure you, Commander, there'll be no retaliation. Cardassia has no desire to go to war again with the Federation. You have my word.
Your word?
Major. I've found our little talk very enlightening.
I hoped you would.
Unfortunately, I have some business to attend to. But I hope you'll take some time and enjoy the station.
Thank you, Commander. But I too must return to my duties. Besides I'm afraid the place has lost its charm since the last time I was here.
I don't believe a word he said.
Neither do I. But he did tell me something I needed to know. Cal was right. The Central Command is smuggling weapons into the Demilitarized Zone.
We've just received a report that three Federation settlers were killed on Hakton Seven. The Cardassians claim it was in response to the destruction of the Bok'Nor.
Which gives the Maquis a new excuse to strike back. Chief, what've you found.
Based on the residual subspace distortion from their warp drive, I was able to plot the course of the Maquis ship that took Dukat.
As you can see, long range sensors show no signs of any other vessels traveling along the same route.
All right, then they didn't transfer him to another ship. What about a planet?
It's possible. Their course took them past five M Class planets. I downloaded their coordinates into the Rio Grande's computer.
Good work. Sisko to Odo.
Yes, Commander.
Find Doctor Bashir and meet me at Landing Pad "C" immediately.
On our way.
Commander, you know there's no reason to go after Dukat. I mean, you heard Legate Parn. They don't want him back.
Are you suggesting we leave him to the Maquis?
Why risk our lives for a man responsible for so many Bajoran deaths? The way I see it, he's getting exactly what he deserves.
(stepping into the Turbolift) Landing Pad "C." The Central Command wants him dead. That's reason enough for us to want him alive.
My mind to your mind... your thoughts to my thoughts...
My mind to your mind... Your thoughts to my thoughts...
(continuing, strained whisper) My mind... to your... mind...
What's wrong?
It's not working. That's what's wrong.
This is quite puzzling. I am unable to establish a mind meld. It would appear he has the ability to shield his thoughts.
It's simply a matter of discipline.
Now what do we do?
After I rest a moment, I will try again.

(in surprising good humor) You people really don't do this very well, do you? Now Cardassians know how to extract information. But it can get rather... unpleasant. And everyone knows how the Federation dislikes unpleasantness.
I share very few sentiments with the Federation.

Oh, that's right. You're renegades, aren't you? Or so you'd like to think. Unfortunately, the Federation has taught you your lessons all too well. You simply lack the... commitment to do what's necessary.
Tell that to the crew of the Bok'Nor.

Anyone can blow up a ship. But to look your enemy in the eye... knowing you'll remember his face for the rest of your life... and still be able to do what's necessary... now that takes a stronger stomach than you'll ever have.
We'll see about that.
No. He's right. We do not possess the Cardassians' gift for inflicting pain.
You see.
Nor would we want such a gift.

But we do need to know when the Central Command's sending its next weapons shipment. So if it's all the same to you, Sakonna... I'll take over the interrogation. This way we can find out just how "committed" I am.
I don't think anyone's that interested.
Put down your weapons. We're not here to fight you.
If that's true, then you'll let us go about our business.
I'm not leaving without Dukat.
Then you're not leaving.
Look, we're on the same side here. We all want to stop the arms shipments. Why not work together.
(to Sisko; an impatient hiss) Stop talking and shoot them.
No. That's not what we want.
What are you waiting for?
Put down your weapons.
Do as he says.
Shoot them.
Let him go.
I said let him go.
Odo, get these people secured on the runabout.
With pleasure, Commander.
Except this one.
You mean I'm free to go?
(to Amaros, urgent but controlled) Tell Cal Hudson I haven't told Starfleet anything yet.
Tell him we can still solve this thing together, but we're running out of time. Tell him I still have his uniform. He can have it back anytime he wants.
Enter.
I just came by to see how you were doing.
I find a good meal to be extremely relaxing, especially after a difficult day.
So do I.
Really. I wonder what else we have in common.
Very little, I imagine.
Other than the fact that you have my office. What's going to happen to your prisoners?
They'll be tried for their crimes under the Federation Uniform Code of Justice.
And if they're found innocent?
I doubt they will be, but if they are, they'll be set free.
How barbaric. On Cardassia, the verdict is always known before the trial begins. And it's always the same.
In that case, why bother with a trial at all?
Because the people demand it. They enjoy watching justice triumph over evil. Every time. They find it comforting.
Isn't there a chance you might try an innocent man by mistake?
Cardassians don't make mistakes.
I'll have to remember that.
One thing does puzzle me, Commander. Surely the Central Command was informed of my kidnapping.
They learned about it almost as soon as it happened.
Then why was I rescued by you? And why wasn't the station surrounded by Cardassian ships demanding my return?
We did receive a visit from Legate Parn.
I'm sure he made some rather ugly threats on my behalf.
He said that you were the one responsible for smuggling weapons into the Demilitarized Zone. And if the Maquis didn't execute you, the Central Command would. After a comforting trial I'm sure.
It appears my relationship with the Central Command has deteriorated somewhat. I knew this was inevitable the moment we withdrew from Bajor.
Are you saying they blame you for the withdrawal?
There are some who believe I should have killed every last Bajoran when I had the chance. Ah, well. Too late for that, I'm afraid. Commander, it seems I was...
Mistaken about the arms shipment?
It appears I was misinformed. I'm beginning to believe the Central Command is smuggling weapons into the Demilitarized Zone after all.
You really didn't know, did you?
(trying to put on a good face) They never bothered to tell me. If I help you stop the smuggling, will you help me stop the Maquis?
You've got yourself a deal. I've called a staff meeting for oh-nine- hundred.
I'll be there.
Oh, and Commander?
Thank you for coming to my rescue.
I'm sure you'd have done the same for me.
Constable, you have the list of weapons Sakonna bought from Quark?
I do. And quite a list it is. Six ship-mounted high energy disrupters, three particle accelerators, two hundred photon torpedoes and a dozen pulse cannons.
With that kind of firepower, the Bajorans could've launched a full- scale assault on Cardassia.
And lost.
Sounds like the Maquis have had their fill of border skirmishes. They're ready for something bigger.
According to Quark, they're planning to launch their first attack any day now.
Have you been able to make any headway with Sakonna?
Have you ever tried interrogating a Vulcan, Lieutenant?
No.
Neither did I until today. I wouldn't advise it. That calm measured voice that tells you nothing, that impassive stare, it can be quite frustrating.
Perhaps I could question her?
I don't think so.
Pity. I like a challenge.
You want a challenge, try finding out how the Central Command is getting weapons into the Demilitarized Zone.
My guess would be by way of a Xepolite Free Trader.
